newsitem.title: JAPAN: Key JGB futures end higher, cash bonds firmer.
newsitem.headline: Key JGB futures end higher, cash bonds firmer.

text.p: Key September Japanese government bond futures closed higher on Wednesday, although they shed some gains after reaching 121.04, their highest level since December 22.
Dealers said long-yield cash JGBs, which pierced one key technical chart point, were particularly strong and lead the bullish mood in the market.
The 10-year JGB auction, the main event of the day, confirmed underlying firm support for the JGBs, they said.
The September contract closed at 120.88, up 0.08 from Tuesday. Volume was 40,284 contracts.
The September opened firm this morning, taking its cue from the Federal Open Market Committee's decision to leave rates unchanged, dealers said.

Although the Fed's decision to leave rates unchanged was largely expected, it prompted last-minute short-covering by those who were hedging their bets on a rate hike by the Fed, said a dealer at a securities firm.
Also in the morning, the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) surprise outright bond buying boosted the market.

After having being blocked a couple of times at strong resistance at 121, the September contract finally managed to climb above 121 in the mid-afternoon, hitting its highest point in almost eight months.
But it failed to hang on to that level for long. "It'd take another fresh factor to bid up the September above 121," said another dealer at a Japanese city bank.

The announcement of 10-year JGB auction results was in line with market expectations. Dealers said there was reasonable demand for the offered bonds. A couple of securities firms are said to have bought large amounts.
A securities firm's dealer said investors' appetites for the auctioned JGBs were strong.
The yield of the cash benchmark 182nd 10-year JGBs dropped below 3.100 percent for the first time since April. As of 0658 GMT, the yield was 3.100 percent, down 0.025 from Tuesday.
Long-end bonds, which had been lagging futures contracts in the recent uptrend, were the main driving force of the bull run today, said a dealer at a city bank's securities unit.
"Everybody may now looking for these bonds to rise further, after the yield broke through 3.1 percent," said a dealer at another city bank's securities affiliate.
